text.2_Daf, 14_Line: ‘All the substitutes for the nazirite vow are equivalent to nazirite vows, and all allusions to the nazirite vow are equivalent to nazirite vows.
text.2_Daf, 26_Line: The following both inherit and bequeath? The truth is that the Tanna adopts sometimes one method and sometimes the other, [according to circumstances].
text.2_Daf, 20_Line: With what materials may [the Sabbath lamp] be kindled, and with what may it not be kindled? and the exposition begins: It is forbidden to kindle etc. [Again, we learn:]
text.2_Daf, 8_Line: The Tanna had in mind the scriptural verse, Then it cometh to pass if she find no favour in his eyes, because he hath found some unseemly thing in her, and he reasons thus.
text.2_Daf, 3_Line: [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I INTEND TO BE LIKE THIS,’ OR ‘I INTEND TO CURL [MY HAIR].’ OR ‘I MEAN TO TEND [MY HAIR].’ OR ‘I UNDERTAKE TO DEVELOP TRESSES,’ HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE.
text.2_Daf, 27_Line: In the first set of cases adduced, because the prohibition is a personal one, this personal prohibition is expounded first.
text.2_Daf, 11_Line: mentions first ‘substitutes’ and then gives examples of ‘allusions’?
text.2_Daf, 10_Line: whosoever sees an unfaithful wife in her degradation will take a nazirite's vow and abjure wine. [How is it that in enunciating the general rule, the Mishnah]
text.2_Daf, 9_Line: What was the cause of the woman's infidelity? Wine. Further, he proceeds,
text.2_Daf, 18_Line: — It is customary for the Tanna to explain first what he mentions last.
text.2_Daf, 25_Line: Some both inherit and bequeath, and some inherit but do not bequeath. Some bequeath and do not inherit, and some neither inherit nor bequeath, whilst the exposition begins:
text.2_Daf, 6_Line: HE DOES NOT BECOME A NAZIRITE.
text.2_Daf, 28_Line: On the other hand, in the case of the animal, since the prohibition arises primarily through the animal, those things which are permitted are mentioned first.
text.2_Daf, 22_Line: It is forbidden to cover etc. [Again:] What may a woman ‘wear when she goes out [on the Sabbath], and what may she not wear when she goes out? and the exposition begins: She must not go out etc.
text.2_Daf, 2_Line: A NAZIK, A NAZIAH A PAZIAH. HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE.
text.2_Daf, 4_Line: [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I TAKE UPON MYSELF [AN OBLIGATION INVOLVING] BIRDS,’ R. MEIR SAYS
text.2_Daf, 21_Line: With what materials may [hot victuals] be covered [on the Sabbath,] and with what may they not be covered? and the exposition begins:
text.2_Daf, 13_Line: There is a hiatus [in the Mishnah] and it should read as follows:
text.2_Daf, 17_Line: Ought not then the substitutes to be enumerated first
text.2_Daf, 24_Line: With what trappings may an animal go out [on the Sabbath]. and with what may it not go out? whilst the exposition begins: The camel may go out etc.; [and again:]
text.2_Daf, 16_Line: If a man says.I shall be [one]." he becomes a nazirite [etc.].’
text.2_Daf, 1_Line: IF A MAN SAYS, ‘I SHALL BE [ONE].’ HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE. [IF HE SAYS.] ‘I SHALL BE COMELY, A NAZIRITE,
text.2_Daf, 5_Line: HE BECOMES A NAZIRITE, BUT THE SAGES SAY
text.2_Daf, 7_Line: [Gemarah]  Seeing that the Tanna is teaching the order Nashim, why does he speak of the nazirite? —
text.2_Daf, 0_Line: [Mishnah]  ALL THE SUBSTITUTES FOR THE NAZIRITE VOW ARE EQUIVALENT TO NAZIRITE VOWS.
